18564.title: Cathedral #2
18564.inscription: inscribed in pencil,  below image, L.L.: 56/75 | signed and dated in pencil, below image, L.R.: Roy Lichtenstein '69

extended_text.content:
In his Cathedral Series of color lithographs made at Gemini G.E.L., Lichtenstein, in his own words, "vulgarized" Monet's classic Impressionist paintings of Rouen Cathedral. He replaced Monet's individualistic broken brushstrokes with a mechanical grid of benday dots common to photographic reproductions.

"They are different from Monet, but they do deal with the Impressionist cliché of not being able to read the image close-up-it becomes clearer as you move away from it."
-Roy Lichtenstein
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

21572.title: Noguchi's Okinawa Woodpecker
21572.credit_line: Gift of the Alliance of the Indianapolis Museum of Art
21572.inscription: inscribed, signed and dated in pencil, L.R.: 43/50 F. Stella '77

extended_text.content:
Stella's "Exotic Bird Series," with titles corresponding to extinct or endangered species, came close to his stated ambition to combine strength and formal inspiration with abandon and exuberance. French curves used by architectural draftsmen are arranged on graph-pattern backgrounds and then loaded with scribbled color and glitter.

Tyler promised the artists who he invited to Tyler Graphics Ltd. that there was nothing they could not try. Stella, in this series, took advantage of the available resources to actively merge lithography, screenprinting  and the hand-application of glitterflex.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

4783.title: Barerra-Rosa's
4783.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: BARERRA ROSA'S 17/29 | signed and dated in pencil, below image, L.R.: COTTINGHAM 1986

extended_text.content:
Cottingham's widely admired ability to draw led to an early invitation to make prints at Landfall in 1973.

"I think of these prints, and my work in general, as a celebration of the signs and urban iconography that have given American cities their peculiar energy."
-Robert Cottingham
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

12731.title: Drypoint--Ocean Surface (Second State)
12731.inscription: signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: V. Celmins | inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: 16 / 55

extended_text.content:
In the tradition of the Old Masters, Celmins gives pause to the constant chaos and motion of the seas, deserts, skies and heavens. She endows her small scale drawings and etchings with their sense of vastness by her uncompromising attention to detail and by foregoing boundaries and horizons.

Gemini hired Doris Simmelink to head their new etching program in 1983. Celmins had previously relied on Simmelink's printing expertise at Crown Point Press in San Francisco.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

4535.title: Second Movement V
4535.inscription: signed and dated in pencil below image L.L.: Anni Albers 1978 | inscribed in pencil below image L.L.: V 3/20
rights: © The Josef and Anni Albers Foundation / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

extended_text.content:
Anni Albers was the wife of abstract artist Josef Albers and was the last surviving teacher of the famed Bauhaus School in Germany in the 1920s. Renowned as a textile designer, her prints, which she did not begin making until the age of 64, depict the same abstract, geometric patterning that made her weaving so influential.

Anni and Josef Albers began making prints with Ken Tyler at Tamarind in 1963. They again collaborated at Gemini G.E.L. and again at Tyler Graphics Ltd. beginning in 1976, the year of Josef Albers' death.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

28506.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: 'Module/Mass'; inscribed in pencil, below image, L.C.: 4/20; signed and dated in pencil, below image, L.R.: Fierke '84

60337.title: Final Holding Cell, Indiana State Prison, Michigan City, IN

extended_text.content:
These photographs by Lucinda Devlin are each part of broader serial projects, in which the artist documents uninhabited architectural interiors. One piece shows a recreation destination from the Pleasure Grounds series, and another documents a spa from the project Corporal Arenas. Other images from those serial projects show motel rooms, discos, tanning booths and medical facilities. Two works are on view from the series The Omega Suites, for which Devlin photographed penitentiaries in twenty states. Each photograph represents the actual location described in its title.

Throughout her work, Devlin uses existing or non-theatrical lighting, and sets her Hasselblad camera at eye level, facing one wall in a room, with perpendicular walls along the sides of the frame. With these works, Devlin intends to show how the structures of particular spaces express the values of those cultures that create and use them.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

60637.title: Airgrid with Green & Grey
60637.description: Medium and Support language approved by Corning curator and modern and contemporary glass specialist Tina Oldknow, Nov. 2013: "fused and blown glass"; additional info: Expanded and fused glass vessel form.
60637.credit_line: Gift of Marilyn and Eugene Glick

35255.title: Preparing for the Matinee
35255.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. John G. Rauch, Sr.
35255.provenance: Washington University, St. Louis 1909 (on loan to the City Art Museum); sold by Kende Galleries in New York May 4, 1945; J.W. Young Art Gallery at Chicago; purchased by John G. Rauch Sr. of Indianapolis; donated to the IMA by Mrs. John G. Rauch Sr.
35255.inscription: signed and dated lower left:   Tarbell-07
35255.subject_description: young woman looking into a mirror, adjusting her hat with a hatpin

extended_text.content:
This lady, concentrating on adjusting her hat with a pearl-tipped hatpin, is typical of Edmund Tarbell's refined, everyday subjects. Like Frank Benson, Tarbell belonged to the Boston School, which flourished during the early decades of the 20th century. These painters were renowned for their pictures of young women engaged in sedentary and often solitary domestic activities, or posed in sunlit outdoor settings. In his interior compositions, Tarbell concentrated upon the insular world of upper-class women, depicting them in an austere but elegant manner, attired in the latest fashions.

The passages of loose, energetic brushwork in her blouse and hair display the spontaneity that Tarbell brought to his outdoor Impressionist paintings. Artists of the Boston School explored aspects of texture, which can be seen in the handling of the creases in the woman's blouse and the feathers on her hat. Tarbell's expert drawing technique is evident in the rendering of the sitter's arm and the handling of her facial features. Like many painters of the Boston School, Tarbell was influenced by the paintings of the 17th-century Dutch artist Jan Vermeer, whose works were rediscovered in the mid-19th century. In fact, a corner of one of Vermeer's paintings appears at the upper right of Tarbell's elegant interior as a tribute to this Dutch master.

[Boston School artists] are more interested in the rendering of beauty than of fact.
-Artist and critic Guy Pène Du Bois, 1915
extended_text.content_type: Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection (2005)
extended_text.title: Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection (2005)

extended_text.content:
The loose energetic brushwork in the woman's blouse and hair are elements of the Impressionist style.

Tarbell was a leading member of the Boston School of painters, known for their pictures of young women engaged in domestic activities.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

extended_text.content:
"This lady, concentrating on adjusting her hat with a pearl-tipped hatpin, is typical of Edmund Tarbell's refined, everyday subjects. Like Frank Benson, Tarbell belonged to the Boston School, which flourished during the early decades of the 20th century. These painters were renowned for their pictures of young women engaged in sedentary and often solitary domestic activities, or posed in sunlit outdoor settings. In his interior compositions, Tarbell concentrated upon the insular world of upper-class women, depicting them in an austere but elegant manner, attired in the latest fashions.

The passages of loose, energetic brushwork in her blouse and hair display the spontaneity that Tarbell brought to his outdoor Impressionist paintings. Artists of the Boston School explored aspects of texture, which can be seen in the handling of the creases in the woman's blouse and the feathers on her hat. Tarbell's expert drawing technique is evident in the rendering of the sitter's arm and the handling of her facial features. Like many painters of the Boston School, Tarbell was influenced by the paintings of the 17th-century Dutch artist Jan Vermeer, whose works were rediscovered in the mid-19th century. In fact, a corner of one of Vermeer's paintings appears at the upper right of Tarbell's elegant interior as a tribute to this Dutch master."

Lee, Ellen Wardwell, Anne Robinson, and Alexandra Bonfante-Warren. Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection. Indianapolis: Indianapolis Museum of Art, 2005, p. 143.
extended_text.title: Edmund Tarbell and the Boston School

extended_text.content:
Edmund Tarbell was the leader of the Boston School, a group of artists who primarily painted women in an impressionistic manner. Other members of the group were Frank Benson, Joseph De Camp, Phillip Leslie Hale, and William Paxton. Tarbell was born in West Groton, Massachusetts, in 1862, and studied at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. He traveled to Paris in 1883, where he attended the Académie Julian with fellow artist Frank Benson. In 1889, Tarbell accepted a post at his Boston alma mater, where he taught painting for twenty-four years. He joined The Ten American Painters, a group formed in opposition to the Society of American Artists and which included America’s leading Impressionists. In 1918, Tarbell became the Director of the Corcoran School of Art in Washington, D. C., where he painted numerous portraits, including Presidents Hoover and Wilson. His reputation and fame, however, rests on his interior genre scenes, which are reminiscent of the seventeenth-century Dutch painter Vermeer.

In Preparing for the Matinee, the lady who is adjusting her hat with a pearl-tipped hatpin is typical of Edmund Tarbell’s refined subjects. The painting imitates elements drawn from several of Vermeer’s paintings and even includes a portion of Vermeer’s The Music Lesson on the wall. The sitter was Charlotte Barton of Boston. In preparation for her sittings, Tarbell requested the shipment of a settee and gilded mirror from his Boston studio. The composition was developed around these props and exemplifies the lifestyle of Boston Brahmin women. Both idealist and impressionistic in style, the painting is an example of Tarbell’s best work.

Strickler, Susan, Erica Hirshler, and Linda Docherty. Impressionism Transformed: The Paintings of Edmund C. Tarbell. Manchester, NH: Currier Gallery of Art, 2001.
extended_text.title: Edmund Tarbell and the Influence of Vermeer

Tarbell,The Currier Gallery of Art, Manchester, New Hampshire, 10/13/2001-01/14/2002  |  Benson/Tarbell Exhibition,Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Massachusetts, 1938  |  Sixteenth Annual Exhibition of American Art,St. Louis Museum of Fine Arts, St. Louis, Missouri, 05/22/1909-07/20/1909  |  Third Annual Exhibition of Selected Paintings by American Artists,Museum of Fine Arts, St. Louis, Missouri, 9/15/1908  |  Exhibition of Paintings by Ten American Painters,The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 04/11/1908-05/03/1908  |  Edmund C. Tarbell,Corcoran Gallery, Washington, D.C., 01/08/1980-01/29/1908

35891.title: Couple in Sumac Thicket
35891.credit_line: Gift of the Contemporary Art Society
rights: © The School of the Art Institute of Chicago and the Brown Family

extended_text.content:
Roger Brown is an artist associated with the Chicago Imagists, a group of artists who graduated from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago who created representational art inspired by everyday pop culture imagery, such as comic books and kitsch. The Chicago Imagists were most active in the late 1960s and early 70s. Brown’s stylized, patterned paintings of interiors and landscapes were often inspired by the folk art that he collected.

Couple in Sumac Thicket depicts two silhouetted figures in a grove of tall plants. For the background, Brown interlaced sections of gray and white to create an undulating pattern of sky and clouds. The foliage is similarly rhythmic, with reeds punctuating the sumac in a curved horizontal line.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

3802.title: day dress
3802.description: raglan sleeves, bias cut bodice, straight grain skirt, bodice and sash and sleeves are all one piece | mid 1970's
3802.provenance: David W. Campbell, New York (Stan Weaver, New York); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1982.

extended_text.content:
Halston used very few prints and patterns in his collections, but he knew the importance of prints for camouflaging problems areas. He preferred abstract and irregular patterns over recognizable motifs.

 

This dress has a very complicated construction. The bodice with its raglan sleeves and the sash were all cut in one piece on the bias, while the skirt was cut on a straight grain. The sash extends from the back of the bodice and ties in the front.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

3802.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

28407.inscription: inscribed, signed and dated in pencil, L.R.: 29/50 Crutchfield 65

56091.title: Mr. No
56091.inscription: signed and dated in pencil below image L.R.: Crutchfield 63; inscribed in pencil L.L.: 2/20; inscribed in pencil L.C.: "Mr. No"

extended_text.content:
"For me, humor in art is the most important humanizing quality," said William Crutchfield. His whimsically robotic Mr. No is the sort of childlike image that Crutchfield began making in 1960 while on a Fulbright scholarship to Germany where, 50 years earlier, Paul Klee had produced similarly delightful whimsies.

Mr. No was the only lithograph produced at Tamarind by Crutchfield in 1963. It was printed by Ken Tyler, who had known Crutchfield as a drawing instructor at the Herron School of Art in Indianapolis the year before.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

25563.title: Laid Up, or In the Cradle
25563.credit_line: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Greenleaf in memory of Caroline Marmon Fesler
25563.provenance: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Greenleaf, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1981.
25563.inscription: signed in pencil, L.R.: A. Hasselman

extended_text.content:
Hasselman served as curator at the John Herron Art Museum (today the Indianapolis Museum of Art) from 1921 to 1952. She also served as an instructor in the affiliated art school.

Hasselman, a specialist in watercolor, went to Provincetown to attend Charles Hawthorne’s Cape Cod School of Art, which had helped established the art colony there in 1899.

Laid Up, featuring a sail boat in its “cradle” of timbers for repairs and repainting, was painted in Provincetown and exhibited at the Philadelphia Water Color Club in 1927.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

25563.exhibit_history: Provincetown, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 05/18/2012 - 11/11/2012 | Whispers to Shouts, Indiana State Museum, Indianapolis, Indiana, 02/05/2005-07/10/2005 |  A Century of American Watercolors, Center for the Arts, Vero Beach, Florida, 09/01/2001-11/11/2001 | Boundries:  A Tradition of Drawing at Herron School of Art,  Herron School of Art, Indianapolis, Indiana, 01/20/1989-02/25/1989|

13785.title: Twin Pines
13785.provenance: Purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1981.
13785.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: 93. | signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: Levon West imp.

extended_text.content:
West was born in South Dakota, but grew up in North Dakota where his father was an itinerant preacher.

After moving east in 1924 his etchings usually reflected his trips abroad, but in the early 1930s he returned periodically to the West of his childhood and his etchings became authentic views of his summers ranching in Wyoming or winters hunting in Montana.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

13785.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

1700.title: Praying Angel
1700.inscription: Inscribed with symbol and monogram, back side, center: [crossed hammer and nail symbol] / RD

extended_text.content:
Robert Davidson

Praying Angel, about 1927

limestone

15 x 5 ¼ x 7 inches

Bequest of Lucy M. Taggart

Learn More

Robert Davidson was born in Indianapolis, Indiana and apprenticed to his artist-father.  He studied sculpture at the John Herron Art Institute in Indianapolis, The Art Institute of Chicago, the School of American Sculpture in New York City, and the Bavarian Fine Arts Academy in Munich Germany.  Davidson’s wife, Maryetta, was an Indiana ceramics artist and also a graduate of John Herron Art Institute.  The couple moved to Saratoga Spring New York where Davidson taught art at Skidmore College.  During his career, Davidson was a member of the Indiana Artists Club and the Chicago Artist Association. 

The best know of Davidson’s early commissions are large concrete plaques that decorate the façade of Indianapolis’ Shortridge High School.  Praying Angel was one of several pieces Davidson placed in national exhibitions during the 1920s.  The bust’s symmetry, spiritual intensity, and even the limestone material recall the statuary of Gothic Cathedrals.

Reference

Artist’s file in the IMA’s Stout Library.
